questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with 3 days of fever and lymphadenopathy. The patient has not had a sore throat, rhinorrhea, or cough and has no known sick contacts. She has not been traveling. She volunteers at an animal shelter in her free time. She has no significant past medical history. Weight is 37th percentile, height is 58th percentile. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 111/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. After the physical examination, blood work is performed which is positive for Bartonella hensalae. Which of the following findings on lymph node examination would be most consistent with the underlying condition?

choices.text: Single tender erythematous cervical lymph node
Immobile, nontender matted cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever and exposure to cats at an animal shelter. Laboratory studies are consistent with infection with Bartonella henelsae, which is the causative agent in Cat-scratch disease. This disease results in regional lymphadenopathy and lymphadenitis (erythematous, tender lymph nodes) typically in the cervical or axillary regions. The hallmark of the disease is regional lymphadenopathy proximal to the site of inoculation. A single tender erythematous cervical lymph node is seen in many cases. 

The differential diagnosis for peripheral lymphadenopathy in children is broad and patients should initially be assessed for signs and symptoms of malignancy. Symptoms concerning malignancy include fever, night sweats, weight loss, bleeding, bruising, and pallor. Lymph node exam typically demonstrates enlarged lymph nodes that are non-tender, firm, and immobile. They may also be matted. The work-up for malignancy includes blood work (including a peripheral smear), chest x-ray, and biopsy. 

If malignancy is ruled out, the next step is to rule out autoimmune diseases that can cause lymphadenopathy. These diseases are typically associated with non-tender, mobile lymph nodes and systemic symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and rash. Physical exam can aid in the diagnosis (e.g., a malar rash is consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus). Kawasaki disease is a clinical diagnosis but for other autoimmune diseases, blood work is often necessary to establish a diagnosis (e.g., Lupus confirmed by the presence of anti-double-stranded DNA and anti-smith antibodies). 

If autoimmune disease is ruled out as the cause of lymphadenopathy, infectious processes should be considered. Lymphadenitis tends to present with a single, erythematous, tender lymph node. Localized infections can cause regional lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenitis and local infections with regional lymphadenopathy tend to be clinical diagnoses; however, if lymphadenitis does not respond to empiric treatment, then further evaluation with a lymph node biopsy or serologic testing for Bartonella henselae is necessary. Viral illnesses can cause generalized lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms and testing for specific viruses can be done with serologies and PCR. However, because they are often self-limited, viral testing may not always be done.   

Option Analysis

✅ Single tender erythematous cervical lymph node:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Generalized lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Generalized lymphadenopathy is found in systemic infections such as viral infections. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area. 
❌ Tender bilateral cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: Tender bilateral cervical lymph nodes can be found with a localized infection of the head and neck such as bilateral otitis media or strep pharyngitis. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single tender erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area. 
❌ Immobile, nontender matted cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: Immobile nontender matted lymph nodes are associated with malignancy. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single tender erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area. 
❌ Nontender supraclavicular lymph nodes :
Incorrect: Nontender Supraclavicular lymph nodes are typically associated with malignancy. This patient has an infection with Bartonella hensalae (i.e., Cat scratch disease) which causes regional lymphadenopathy and often a single tender erythematous lymph node is present in the cervical or axillary area.

questions.text:
A three-day-old newborn girl is being evaluated for a rash that suddenly appeared on her trunk. Her parents brought her immediately to the emergency department where she was triaged. She was born at 37-weeks of gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery without peripartum complications. Weight is 85th percentile, length is 80th percentile, and head circumference is 85th percentile. Rectal temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), heart rate is 185/min, and blood pressure is 70/47 mmHg. The patient is sleeping in the mother’s arms but is arousable and moves all four extremities equally. Physical examination reveals an erythematous rash with clear demarcation along the midline on the trunk as seen in the image below. The hands and feet are warm and pink. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


 [URL: https://www.pediatriconcall.com/spot-diagnosis/color-change/186. Image taken from script.]
questions.solution:
This three-day-old newborn girl presents with sudden onset of an erythematous rash on the trunk with a clear demarcation along the midline consistent with Harlequin color change. This benign condition is characterized by unilateral transient color change.    

Patients with Harlequin color change have sudden onset of unilateral redness that typically resolves within 20 minutes. On physical examination when the infant is placed on their side, unilateral erythema is seen on the dependent side with a clear demarcation along the midline. Blanching can be observed on the nondependent side. While the color change may appear dramatic, this phenomenon is benign, self-limited, and does not require intervention.   

The cause of Harlequin color change is unknown, but it may be related to immaturity of autonomic regulation of cutaneous blood vessel tone. It is more commonly seen in preterm infants vs. term infants and typically appears before one week of age. It typically resolves on its own after 20 minutes.  



Option Analysis

✅ Harlequin color change :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Physiologic desquamation :
Incorrect: Physiologic desquamation most commonly occurs in post-term neonates, and patients present with skin peeling or desquamation of the hands and feet. Peeling may extend to the limbs or trunk. This patient has no evidence of desquamation on physical examination.
❌ Acrocyanosis :
Incorrect: Acrocyanosis is typically seen in newborns who are less than 2 days old. It refers to color changes of the distal extremities that resolve with warming. Physical examination typically reveals cool and blue skin over the involved distal extremities. The trunk remains warm and well-profused. This patient’s extremities are warm and pink.
❌ Cutis marmorata :
Incorrect: Patients with cutis marmorata exhibit widespread symmetrical mottling of the skin with cold exposure that improves with warming. It can occur any time during the first few months of life. It appears as a lacy or reticulated purple or pink rash on the trunk, arms, and legs.
❌ Congenital dermal melanocytosis :
Incorrect: Congenital dermal melanocytosis is a birthmark seen in newborns that appears similar to a bruise. It can appear as a bluish-gray spot on the back, extremities, or buttocks and may be mistaken for non-accidental trauma.

questions.text:
A five-day-old boy born at 39-weeks of gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery is brought by his parents to the primary care office for a facial rash. Weight is in the 90th percentile, length is in the 95th percentile, and head circumference is in the 90th percentile. Rectal temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), heart rate is 183/min, and blood pressure is 73/50 mmHg. The patient is awake and calm in the father’s arms and moves all extremities equally. Physical examination shows numerous 1-2 mm sized whitish-yellow colored smooth papules over the face, nose, and cheeks as seen in the image below. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?



[URL: https://www.gponline.com/glance-sebaceous-gland-hyperplasia-vs-milia/paediatrics/article/1057176. Image taken from script]
questions.solution:
This five-day old boy presents with numerous tiny white-yellow papules that are 1-2 mm in size on the nose and cheeks. This rash is consistent with sebaceous hyperplasia, which is caused by androgenic stimulation of the sebaceous glands in newborns. The rash is a benign and transient condition that typically resolves on its own or with conservative management.    

Typically, rashes that appear in well-appearing afebrile newborns are benign. Diagnosis can typically be made clinically using history provided by a caregiver and the physical exam. However, if the diagnosis is unclear, cytologic examination (e.g. of fluid from a pustule) can be used to help make the diagnosis.    

Features to consider when making the diagnosis of a rash in a newborn is the time of onset of the rash, whether or not the rash is transient, and the distribution of the rash.  Rashes that typically appear before one week of age include physiologic desquamation, Harlequin color change, acrocyanosis, cutis marmorata, transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM), erythema toxicum nonatorum (ETN), sebaceous gland hyperplasia, and milia.  

Newborn and infant rashes can be caused by hormonal shifts, immature circulation, and environmental exposures. Occasionally, rashes may be idiopathic. The table below lists common newborn rashes by age and their etiologies.



Option Analysis

✅ Androgenic stimulation of sebaceous glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Exposure to warm environment:
Incorrect: Patients with miliaria have a widespread, vesicular, erythematous rash following exposure to warm environments. The lesions seen in this newborn are papular and not vesicular (fluid filled) and are localized to the nose and cheeks, which is more consistent with sebaceous hyperplasia. 
❌ Exposure to cold environment:
Incorrect: Patients with cutis marmorata present with symmetric mottling of the skin, typically after cold exposure and have a lacy, reticulated purple or pink colored rash over the trunk, arms, and legs. This newborn’s rash appears as a whitish-yellow papular rash localized to the nose and cheeks that is more consistent with sebaceous gland hyperplasia. 
❌ Sebum overproduction:
Incorrect: Sebum overproduction can result in seborrheic dermatitis, or “cradle cap.” Patients with seborrheic dermatitis can present with a greasy, flaky rash involving the scalp, face, ears, or neck. This newborn’s rash appears as a whitish-yellow papular rash localized to the nose and cheeks that is more consistent with sebaceous gland hyperplasia. 
❌ Vasomotor immaturity:
Incorrect: Acrocyanosis may be seen in newborns due to vasomotor immaturity. Patients with acrocyanosis present with bluish discoloration in the hands and feet when exposed to the cold. This newborn’s rash appears as a whitish-yellow papular rash localized to the face, nose, and cheeks that is more consistent with sebaceous gland hyperplasia.

questions.text:
A three-day-old newborn girl is being evaluated for a rash. She was born at 40-weeks of gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Her mother says the rash first began two days after birth as multiple small red flat and raised lesions on the trunk. The rash appeared spontaneously and was not associated with exposure to temperature changes. Weight is in the 85th percentile, length is in the 85th percentile, and head circumference is in the 90th percentile. The patient is sleeping but is arousable and moves all four extremities equally. Rectal temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), heart rate is 183/min, and blood pressure is 73/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows numerous macules on erythematous bases with central pustules on the trunk as seen in the image below. No rash is seen over mucosal, palmar, or plantar surfaces. Cytologic examination of pustular fluid from one of the lesions reveals a predominance of eosinophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


[URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4372928/. Image taken from script]
questions.solution:
This three-day old newborn presents with a rash made up of macules on erythematous bases with central pustules that is located on the trunk. Cytology shows a predominance of eosinophils. These findings are consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN).    

ETN usually begins 2-3 days after birth as a rash made up of multiple erythematous macules and papules (1 to 3 mm in size) that quickly develop central pustules on an erythematous base. The lesions typically are distributed over the trunk and proximal extremities and spare the palms and soles. Lesions can mimic the appearance of flea bites.    

Cytologic examination of fluid from the pustules can help make the diagnosis and differentiate it from transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM), which is a widespread pustular rash seen in the newborn period. In the case of ETN, cytology will show a predominance of eosinophils. Conversely, a predominance of neutrophils with occasional eosinophils will be seen on cytology with transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM).    

Risk factors for ETN include higher birth weight, greater gestational age, and vaginal delivery. A correlation has been found between the length of labor and the incidence and duration of ETN. ENT is a benign condition that typically resolves spontaneously within 10 days.  

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM):
Incorrect: Patients with transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM) typically present at the time of birth with widespread vesiculopustular lesions on a non-erythematous base that may occur over the palms and soles. This newborn has a rash that consists of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles that began two days after birth, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN). 
❌  Miliaria :
Incorrect: Patients with miliaria present with a widespread rash made up of tiny scattered vesicles that may appear erythematous. The rash can appear after exposure to a warm environment. This patient’s rash appeared spontaneously and consists of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN). 
❌ Milia:
Incorrect: Patients with milia typically present with firm, pearly yellow papules that are 1-3 mm in size on the face, nose, chin, or forehead made up of benign Keratin-containing cysts. This patient’s rash consists of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN). 
❌ Seborrheic dermatitis :
Incorrect: Patients with seborrheic dermatitis, or “cradle cap,” present with a greasy, flaky rash involving the scalp, face, ears, or neck. Lesions appear as yellow, scaly patches on an erythematous base. This patient has a rash made up of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful desquamating rash that has developed over the past two days. The patient reports preceding symptoms of fever, malaise, and nausea. The rash began on her face but now involves her arms, mouth, chest, and back. The patient has a past medical history of HIV, is prescribed antiretroviral therapy, and has had several recent medication changes—including the initiation of nevirapine. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 107/60 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has multiple areas of dusky erythema, purpura, and flaccid bullae over her arms, chest, and back, and face. She has ulcerative lesions in the oropharynx. Skin biopsy is performed, which reveals full-thickness necrolysis and separation of the epidermis at the dermo-epidermal junction. In addition to discontinuing nevirapine, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous fluids, wound care, and nutritional support

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with a desquamating rash following the initiation of nevirapine has a skin biopsy that reveals findings consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Treatment of patients with SJS/TEN should start with discontinuation of the causative medication if one is identified. The rest of the management is largely supportive, including wound care, fluid and electrolyte management, nutritional support, temperature management, pain control, and infection prevention.    

Due to extensive skin sloughing in patients with SJS/TEN, patients are at high risk for significant volume loss and temperature dysregulation; they should receive appropriate fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion. Exposed tissue from skin sloughing predisposes patients to the development of infection, and patients should receive appropriate biological dressings and surgeries if necessary.  

Evidence for the use of immunosuppressive therapies in SJS/TEN is limited. Meta Analyses have shown potential benefit from cyclosporine, etanercept, systemic corticosteroids, and combination intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and systemic corticosteroids.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous fluids, wound care, and nutritional support:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin:
Incorrect: Supportive care remains the mainstay of treatment for patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Immunosuppressive therapies may be used in certain cases, but evidence of their efficacy is limited.
❌ Cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Supportive care remains the mainstay of treatment for patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Immunosuppressive therapies may be used in certain cases, but evidence of their efficacy is limited.
❌ Etanercept:
Incorrect: Supportive care remains the mainstay of treatment for patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Immunosuppressive therapies may be used in certain cases, but evidence of their efficacy is limited.
❌ Intravenous valacyclovir:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) based on skin biopsy results. Intravenous valacyclovir is not indicated in the treatment of SJS/TEN

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful rash that developed one day prior. The patient reports preceding symptoms of fever, malaise, and nausea. The rash began on her chest and face but now also involves the back and both arms, and she has new lesions in her mouth. The patient was started on sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim two weeks ago for treatment of a urinary tract infection. The patient has a past medical history of HIV and is currently on antiretroviral therapy. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is bilateral conjunctival erythema. There are multiple ulcerative lesions in the oropharynx. Skin exam shows multiple areas of dusky erythema, purpura, target lesions, and flaccid bullae overlying her arms, chest, and back. Once the patient is stabilized, which of the following is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge with primary care follow-up in two days

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of HIV presents with an extensive rash with mucocutaneous involvement and hemodynamic instability after being started on sulfamethoxazole. The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Patients with HIV are at increased risk of developing SJS/TEN. Patients with these conditions should be treated in an intensive care unit (ICU) and/or burn center.    

SJS and TEN are rare immune-mediated mucocutaneous conditions characterized by widespread blistering and sloughing of the skin. The exact cause of these conditions is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve type 4 hypersensitivity against certain antigens, including certain medications and pathogens. Frequently implicated drugs include anticonvulsants, sulfasalazine, sulfamethoxazole (as seen in this patient), allopurinol, and nevirapine.  

Many patients with SJS/TEN are critically ill and require stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. The remainder of acute care includes wound care, fluid and electrolyte management, nutritional support, temperature management, pain control, and infection prevention along with surgical consultation. Due to extensive skin sloughing, these patients are at high risk for significant volume losses and temperature dysregulation, and they should receive appropriate fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion. Exposed tissue from skin sloughing predisposes them to infection, and they should receive appropriate biological dressings. Importantly, these patients should have their medication list examined and potential causative medications should be immediately discontinued. 

Option Analysis

✅ Transfer to a burn center :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Discharge on oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe, potentially life-threatening conditions that require inpatient treatment, often in a specialized burn unit or burn center due to the risk of significant dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, infection, and other complications. Outpatient management with oral antibiotics would be inadequate.
❌ Admit to the medical floor:
Incorrect: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) should not be admitted to the general medical floor. These patients are at high risk for developing secondary infections, multi-organ failure, and critical illness. They should be admitted to an intensive care unit and/or burn center.
❌ Admit for 24-hour observation:
Incorrect: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are not appropriate candidates for 24-hour observation. These patients are at high risk of developing secondary infections, multi-organ failure, and critical illness.They should be admitted to an intensive care unit and/or burn center.
❌ Discharge with primary care follow-up in two days:
Incorrect: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are not appropriate candidates for discharge with primary care follow-up. These patients are at high risk of developing secondary infections, multi-organ failure, and critical illness. They should be admitted to an intensive care unit and/or burn center.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old woman presents to the emergency department from an assisted living facility for evaluation of a rash. The patient’s nurse from the facility reports the patient has had flu-like symptoms for the past two days and that today she noticed a desquamating truncal rash that progressed to involve all extremities. The patient has a past medical history of Alzheimer dementia, hypertension, diabetes, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. Three weeks ago, she was treated with sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim after she developed a urinary tract infection that was resistant to ciprofloxacin. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 97/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears ill and is unable to provide further clinical history. She has conjunctival erythema and oral lesions. Skin examination is notable for the findings shown below. Which of the following tests will lead to a definitive diagnosis?


 Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with prodromal symptoms, a desquamating rash, conjunctival erythema, and oral lesions following the initiation of sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) caused by sulfamethoxazole. While largely a clinical diagnosis, definitive diagnosis can be achieved via skin biopsy, which will reveal full-thickness necrolysis and separation of the epidermis at the dermo-epidermal junction.    

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are rare immune-mediated mucocutaneous conditions characterized by widespread blistering and sloughing. Stevens-Johnson syndrome is diagnosed when the percent of body surface area affected is less than 10%. TEN is diagnosed when the percent of body surface area affected is more than 30%. SJS/TEN overlap is diagnosed when 10% to 30% of the body surface area is affected. The Wallace rule of nines can be used to estimate the amount of body surface area affected.  

Workup for patients with SJS/TEN should include a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), c-reactive protein (CRP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), as well as blood cultures and a skin biopsy. Typically, patients demonstrate elevations in the white blood cell count and inflammatory markers, and they may have positive blood cultures if there is associated infection. The CMP may reveal electrolyte imbalances and elevated BUN and creatinine. CT chest imaging should also be considered for patients with pulmonary symptoms to assess for associated pneumonitis. Skin biopsy can rule out other conditions in the differential diagnosis, such as erythema multiforme, exanthematous drug eruptions, or staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.  



Option Analysis

✅ Skin biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antinuclear antibodies:
Incorrect: Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are associated with multiple immune mediated conditions. A positive ANA does not help to diagnose Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest:
Incorrect: A CT chest may reveal evidence of pneumonitis, suggestive of severe disease from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). However, this does not definitively diagnose SJS/TEN. 
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: A tzank smear can be used to diagnose varicella-zoster or herpes simplex virus. Skin biopsy is the definitive diagnostic modality for patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: A lumbar puncture may be useful for diagnosing associated meningitis in patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN); however, it is not used to diagnose this condition. Skin biopsy is the definitive diagnostic modality for patients with SJS/TEN.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful, rapidly-spreading rash involving his trunk, extremities, and face that started 24 hours ago. The patient reports preceding symptoms of fever and malaise. He states the rash started on his face and chest yesterday and that today the rash extended to his back and all extremities; he also developed lesions in his mouth. He has a past medical history of obesity, hypertension treated with amlodipine, and gout for which allopurinol was started one month prior. The patient returned from an uncomplicated medical mission trip to South America three months ago. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 112/60 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On skin examination, the patient has extensive dusky erythema, flaccid bullae, and painful erythema of the palms and soles bilaterally. He has bilateral conjunctival erythema. Findings from the oral exam are seen below. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following most likely contributed to the development of the underlying condition?



  Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a painful rapidly-spreading rash with flaccid bullae, oral lesions, and bilateral conjunctivitis likely has Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is the recent initiation of allopurinol.  

Characteristic clinical features of SJS/TEN include prodromal flu-like symptoms (e.g. cough, sore throat, malaise, fever), followed by development of a characteristic rash. Lesions typically begin on the face and chest and are symmetrically distributed. Early lesions appear as coalescing, erythematous macules, which evolve to dusky erythema, purpuric spots, and flaccid bullae. Mucosal involvement (i.e. mouth, perineum, or eyes) is highly suggestive of the disease. The rash can progress to extensive sheet-like detachment of the skin and erosions, and positive Nikolsky sign can be seen (i.e. extension of epidermal detachment with gentle lateral pressure applied). Physical examination may also reveal findings associated with pulmonary and renal involvement.  

All patients with SJS/TEN should have a careful history performed to assess for potential causative medications as most cases are caused by medications. Medications highly associated with this disease process include anticonvulsants, sulfasalazine, sulfamethoxazole, allopurinol, certain NSAIDS, and nevirapine (which is used to treat HIV). Infections may also cause SJS/TEN. Risk factors for SJS/TEN include a history of immunodeficiency, HIV, active malignancy, and older age.   

Option Analysis

✅ Allopurinol use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amlodipine use:
Incorrect: Amlodipine is not typically associated with the development of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. 
❌ Recent travel to South America:
Incorrect: Infections can cause Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. However, the patient had no noted infections during or immediately after his trip, and his travel was months prior to the onset of symptoms.
❌ History of hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a risk factor for the development of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. 
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Older patients are at increased risk of developing Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. This patient's age would not be a contributing risk factor.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of acne. He has had acne for several years but noticed it has worsened in the past few months. He has tried an over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide wash and topical retinoid cream without improvement. He has multiple bright red pustules and acneiform papules on the forehead and cheeks on physical examination. He was prescribed doxycycline for three months, which leads to symptomatic improvement. However, after six months, the patient’s symptoms worsened. What is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to this class of antibiotics?

choices.text: Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala

questions.solution:
Doxycycline and other tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics that inhibit the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, thereby preventing attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. Doxycycline is commonly used in the treatment of acne vulgaris.

Bacteria can develop resistance to tetracyclines primarily by forming plasmid-encoded transport pumps that decrease the uptake or increase the efflux of tetracyclines out of the cell. Other proposed resistance mechanisms include ribosomal protection and bacterial modification of tetracycline molecules, reducing the drug’s effectiveness.  

Option Analysis

✅ Plasmid-encoded transport pumps  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial transferase enzymes:
Incorrect: This is how bacteria develop resistance to aminoglycoside antibiotics (e.g., gentamicin, neomycin, amikacin, tobramycin, streptomycin). These enzymes inactive the drugs through adenylation, phosphorylation, or acetylation.  
❌ Carbapenemases:
Incorrect: This is how bacteria develop resistance to carbapenems (e.g., doripenem, imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem). These antibiotics are not used in the routine treatment of acne vulgaris.  
❌ Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to vancomycin. D-Ala D-Ala is converted to D-Ala D-Lac, preventing vancomycin from binding to the bacterial cell wall.  
❌ Methylation of 23S rRNA-binding site:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how bacteria develop resistance to macrolide antibiotics. Methylation of the site prevents the binding of drug molecules to the ribosome.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pain in the right lower extremity. The patient was running on the beach without shoes over the past weekend and sustained a small laceration to the bottom of the foot. Over the past 24 hours, he has been experiencing severe pain and swelling of the foot to the point that he is unable to bear weight. He is otherwise healthy and does not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit substances. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 131/72 mmHg. On physical examination, a 3 cm x 3 cm area of erythema is noted on the underside of the right foot. The patient is exquisitely tender to palpation over the entire aspect of the right foot extending to the mid tibia. A radiograph of the right foot is obtained and demonstrates the following finding:



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam dual therapy

questions.solution:
This patient has right foot cellulitis, pain out of proportion to physical exam findings, and radiograph demonstrating air in the soft tissue. Together, these findings are consistent with necrotizing fasciitis, which must be treated emergently with surgical debridement of devitalized tissue.

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rare but serious infection of deep soft tissues that results in rapid, progressive destruction of muscle fascia and overlying subcutaneous fat. Typically, bacteria (usually anaerobes or Streptococcus pyogenes) with appropriate toxin-carrying capabilities enter through broken skin and spread along the myofascial plane. Pyrogenic exotoxins induce cytokine production, contributing to tissue destruction and subsequent production of methane and CO2. Ultimately, this process causes bullae formation, crepitus, and gas within soft tissue.

Necrotizing fasciitis carries a high rate of morbidity and mortality. Therefore, prompt recognition and treatment are paramount. Clues to the diagnosis include pain out of proportion to physical exam findings, erythema without sharp margins, as well as skin bullae and necrosis. Definitive treatment includes debridement of devitalized tissue for source control, as well as empiric antibiotics that include either carbapenem or piperacillin-tazobactam plus vancomycin and clindamycin. This combination is effective against both Gram positive and anaerobic pathogens. Furthermore, clindamycin helps inhibit bacterial toxin production.



Option Analysis

✅ Surgical debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Intravenous ceftriaxone monotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has pain out of proportion to physical exam findings. Furthermore, the radiograph demonstrates accumulation of air within the subcutaneous tissue. These findings are suggestive of necrotising fasciitis, which is often caused by Gram positive and anaerobic bacteria. Ceftriaxone lacks adequate coverage to treat this type of infection.
❌ Below the knee amputation:
Incorrect: This patient should be taken to the operating room for surgical exploration. Attempts to debride the infected tissue and save the limb should be attempted before proceeding to amputation.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam dual therapy:
Incorrect: Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam reflects incomplete antibiotic therapy for necrotizing soft tissue infections. Clindamycin should also be added, since the antibiotic decreases toxin production by bacteria.
❌ Incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Simple incision and drainage is performed for skin abscesses. In contrast, necrotizing soft tissue infections would need to undergo surgical debridement.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a rash on his chest. The patient had a burning pain across his right chest last week, followed by the eruption of painful blisters two days ago. The patient has a history of a kidney transplant due to underlying diabetes and hypertension. The patient is currently taking tacrolimus daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 156/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the finding as shown. Which of the following pathogens is most likely implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with herpes zoster or shingles, as manifested by the small clustered vesicular lesions in the T3 dermatome across the right chest that do not cross the midline. The organism known to induce this dermatologic finding is human-herpesvirus 3 (HHV-3).   

Shingles refers to the reactivation of a latent infection with the varicella-zoster virus, or HHV-3 – the same pathogen associated with childhood chickenpox. After the primary infection has subsided, the virus remains latent in the dorsal root or trigeminal nerve ganglia, typically for decades. Without proper vaccination, the virus harbors the risk of reactivation (especially in immunocompromised patients) within the ganglion to involve multiple sensory neurons and spread down the sensory nerve to establish infection in the skin.  

Clinically, this condition manifests with a rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome or several contiguous dermatomes. Over the next several days, the rash develops into small vesicles, which become pustular. As this process occurs, the involved sensory ganglion exhibits intense inflammation and hemorrhagic necrosis of nerve cells, resulting in post-herpetic neuralgia, the most common complication of shingles.    

Most commonly, reactivation occurs on the trunk; however, when reactivation occurs in the distribution of trigeminal V1, ocular involvement may occur. In this case, patients may also experience hearing loss, facial paralysis, or loss of taste, known as Ramsay-hunt syndrome. Less common complications include meningitis, encephalitis, myelitis, or bacterial superinfection in immunocompromised hosts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Varicella-zoster virus (Human-herpes-virus 3) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect:  Staphylococcus aureus is a well-established cause of purulent cellulitis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Epstein Barr virus:
Incorrect:  The Epstein Barr virus, also known as HHV-4, is the most common culprit implicated in the setting of infectious mononucleosis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Human-herpes-virus 6:
Incorrect: Human herpesvirus 6 is the pathogen most commonly associated with roseola infantum in children, which typically presents with a few days of high-grade fever followed by the eruption of a blanching maculopapular rash. This patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus is the most common etiology of infectious mononucleosis in heterophile-negative patients; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful skin rash. The patient had a mole removed from the tip of his nose last week. He broke out in a painful facial rash over the weekend and has subsequently been experiencing fevers and chills. Past medical history is notable for poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, lymphedema, and a left kidney transplant for which he is on tacrolimus. The patient develops hives when he takes penicillin. At arrival, temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 161/82 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a facial rash that is consistent with erysipelas. Erysipelas can be treated using a penicillin or second or third generation cephalosporin. Given the patient has signs of systemic infection (e.g., fevers, chills), is taking an immunosuppressive drug, and has a penicillin allergy, intravenous cefazolin would be the most appropriate treatment option.

Erysipelas is an infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics within the skin. It is characterized clinically by well-defined, raised demarcations of erythema. The infection is most commonly found on the lower extremities and face, with Streptococcus pyogenes being the culprit in the overwhelming majority of cases. Risk factors for developing erysipelas include breaks in the skin, poorly controlled diabetes, lymphedema, and an immunocompromised state.

Treatment of erysipelas involves administering antibiotics that provide coverage for Streptococcus pyogenes; typically an oral penicillin is used. In patients with signs of systemic infection or immunocompromised state, an intravenous penicillin or cephalosporin should be administered instead.



Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous cefazolin:
Correct: See main explanation
❌ Oral amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Oral amoxicillin is an appropriate treatment for patients without findings of systemic infection or immunosuppression. In contrast, this patient has signs of systemic infection (e.g., fever, chills) and is taking the immunosuppressant drug tacrolimus. Furthermore, this patient has an allergy to medications in the penicillin family.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin:
Incorrect: Erysipelas is rarely due to methicillin resistant strains of Staphylococcus aureus. While intravenous vancomycin would likely cover Streptococcus pyogenes, which is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s erysipelas, the antibiotic is too broad for this patient’s clinical condition.
❌ Topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical mupirocin is the treatment for localized impetigo, which is characterized by golden crusted lesions. In contrast, erysipelas requires treatment with systemic antibiotics.
❌ Oral acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is the treatment of choice for patients presenting with herpes simplex or herpes zoster. This patient has erysipelas, which is a bacterial skin infection, and acyclovir would be ineffective in treating the condition.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a painful rash over the left side of his face for the past four days. He reports his symptoms were preceded by malaise and low grade fevers at home. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and chickenpox in his youth. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 154/70 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, a vesicular rash is noted in the V1 distribution over the left face. Several vesicles are noted over the distal left tip of the nose. The rash does not cross the midline of the face. Mental status and neurologic exams are within normal limits. Which of the following diagnostic studies should be performed next?

choices.text: Fluorescein stain of the left eye

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with herpes zoster infection (shingles). There is evidence of infection in the V1 distribution of the trigeminal nerve with a rash at the tip of the nose (Hutchinson sign). These findings warrant further investigation of ocular involvement with fluorescein staining to rule out herpes zoster ophthalmicus. If present, fluorescein staining will reveal epithelial keratitis that can evolve into pseudodendrites.

Herpes zoster infection, also known as shingles, occurs in individuals who have had a primary infection with the varicella-zoster virus. Following the primary infection (“chickenpox”), the virus remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia of spinal nerves or the trigeminal ganglion. In times of stress or immunosuppression, the virus can reactivate and travel down the sensory neurons, causing herpes zoster.

Patients with herpes zoster classically present with a unilateral rash that does not cross midline that is present in 1 or 2 adjacent dermatomes. The rash initially begins as a maculopapular rash that progresses to vesicles and may coalesce to bullae. The rash typically lasts between 10-15 days. Patients often have a prodrome of malaise, headache, and low grade fever prior to the appearance of the rash. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus occurs when the virus reactivates in the trigeminal ganglion and travels down the ophthalmic nerve. This can affect all parts of the eye, including the retina, and can cause retinal detachment and necrosis, which can compromise longstanding vision. When this rash is present over the face in a V1 distribution, a thorough ocular examination should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fluorescein stain of the left eye:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HIV viral load:
Incorrect: Patients with herpes zoster may be screened for HIV as it is a risk factor for developing the condition. However, the V1 distribution in this case confers a high risk for herpes zoster ophthalmicus, warranting a thorough evaluation of the eye.  
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: Tzanck smear can be performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster remains unclear, but the diagnosis can be made clinically in this case.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture should be performed for patients with evidence of herpes zoster and encephalitis. This patient has no evidence of encephalitis.  
❌ Viral culture:
Incorrect: Varicella zoster viral culture can be performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster remains unclear. In this patient, the diagnosis can be made clinically.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a painful red rash for the past three days. He reports burning over the skin as well as generalized malaise prior to the onset of the rash. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He has a history of chickenpox in childhood. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 145/70 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. The patient’s rash is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the best next step for diagnosing his condition?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with herpes zoster infection (shingles), which can be diagnosed clinically based on the presence of a typical rash. The typical rash is a unilateral, erythematous maculopapular or vesicular rash that is in 1 or 2 adjacent dermatomes.

The rash of herpes zoster typically lasts between 10-15 days. Patients often have a prodrome of malaise, headache, and low grade fevers prior to the appearance of the rash. When the diagnosis is unclear, further testing can include Tzanck smear, viral culture, serology, and PCR. Patients with concern for disseminated herpes zoster, which can present with associated hepatitis, encephalitis, or meningitis, require further workup with a lumbar puncture, blood work, and imaging.  

Option Analysis

✅ No further testing is required:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: Liver function tests should be performed if there is concern for disseminated herpes zoster. This patient does not demonstrate signs, symptoms, or risk factors for disseminated disease.  
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: Tzanck smear can be performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster is unclear. However, the diagnosis can be made clinically in this patient presenting with a typical rash.  
❌ Viral PCR testing:
Incorrect: Varicella-zoster virus DNA can be detected using PCR testing, though this is typically only performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster is unclear. The diagnosis can be made clinically in this patient with a typical rash.  
❌ Viral serologic testing:
Incorrect: Antibodies against varicella-zoster virus can be detected, though it is typically only performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster is unclear. The diagnosis can be made clinically in this patient with a typical rash.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the hospital with four days of erythema, pain, and swelling of the right leg. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and major depressive disorder. Current medications include carvedilol and fluoxetine. Medication allergies include doxycycline, penicillin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Temperature is 100.4 ºF (38 ºC), heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 138/79 mmHg. On physical examination, there is erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the right leg extending from a 2 cm wound at the lateral malleolus up to the tibial plateau. Wound culture is positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is treated with intravenous vancomycin and is transitioned to oral linezolid on the day of discharge. He is counseled on risks and possible side effects of this medication. Which of the following side effects may occur due to drug-drug interactions?
questions.solution:
This patient on fluoxetine has evidence of right leg cellulitis and a wound infected with methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). Several oral antibiotics can be used to treat MRSA, such as doxycycline, linezolid and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Linezolid works well against gram-positive bacteria (including MRSA); however, linezolid also has weak monoamine oxidase inhibitory (MAOI) activity. For this reason, linezolid can increase levels of norepinephrine and serotonin, which can lead to serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is due to abnormally high levels of serotonin, and generally occurs in patients taking multiple serotonergic medications (e.g., linezolid, MAOI, SNRI, SSRI). It is a clinical diagnosis and often manifests with agitation, clonus, hyperreflexia and hyperthermia. Other clinical manifestations include diaphoresis, dry mucous membranes, and overactive bowels. Treatment is centered on stopping the offending medication and providing supportive care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Agitation and hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bradykinesia and micrographia:
Incorrect: These are features that can be seen with drug-induced Parkinsonism or Parkinson disease. Linezolid does not cause Parkinsonism.
❌ Involuntary mouth movements:
Incorrect: Tardive dyskinesia can result from overuse or use of multiple anti-dopaminergic medications.
❌ Muscle breakdown:
Incorrect: Rhabdomyolysis has been rarely associated with daptomycin, an intravenous agent that can be used to treat methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Linezolid is not associated with rhabdomyolysis.
❌ Sunburn:
Incorrect: Photosensitivity can occur in patients taking doxycycline, another agent that can be used to treat methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Linezolid is not associated with severe/more frequent sunburns (photosensitivity).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of fever and rash. His symptoms started 5 days ago with a high-grade fever, malaise, and loss of appetite. It was followed by the appearance of a macular rash on his trunk and face. Last night, the patient noticed similar rashes on his extremities. The rash is intensely pruritic and has evolved into pustules and vesicles. He continued to develop new lesions as the old ones crusted and healed. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. In addition to providing supportive care, which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with multiple pruritic maculopapular rashes followed by successive crops of vesicles in different stages is consistent with primary varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection. Treatment with valacyclovir is indicated in this patient to prevent the development of complications (e.g. pneumonia).  

Valacyclovir is the prodrug of acyclovir that gets converted to acyclovir in the liver and has better bioavailability than acyclovir when given orally. It has a longer duration of action than acyclovir and is currently approved for use in herpes simplex virus (HSV) and VZV infections.   

Famciclovir is similar to acyclovir in its structure and requirement for phosphorylation but differs slightly in its mode of action. After absorption, the agent is converted to penciclovir, which inhibits viral DNA polymerase. However, it does not irreversibly terminate DNA replication. It is currently approved for the treatment of HSV and VZV infections. Penciclovir is also approved for topical treatment of recurrent herpes labialis.    

The most commonly encountered clinical mutants of HSV are thymidine kinase-deficient and are cross-resistant to valacyclovir and famciclovir.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: Gabapentin is indicated for the management of neuropathic pain secondary to postherpetic neuralgia. It is not effective for the treatment of acute primary VZV infection.
✅ Valacyclovir:
Correct: 
  1.  Varicella-zoster vaccination 
❌ Varicella-zoster vaccination:
Incorrect: Varicella-zoster vaccination is indicated for prophylaxis against varicella-zoster virus infection. It is not effective for the treatment of acute primary VZV infection.
❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect:  Fluconazole is an antifungal agent that is effective against local fungal infections such as candidiasis. This patient most likely has a primary VZV infection.
❌ Permethrin:
Incorrect: Permethrin is an effective treatment option for scabies which presents with a pruritic rash in the web spaces of the hand and groin. It does not cause an evolving maculopapular and vesicular rash. Permethrin is not effective against viral infections.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of yellow discoloration of her toes. She has noticed that the nail of her great toe has begun to separate from the underlying nail bed. The patient does not have pain, redness, or associated swelling. Her past medical history includes type 1 DM and gout. Her only current medication is NPH insulin. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes every day for the last 20 years. She does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals splitting, yellowing, discoloration, and separation of the toes of her right foot as demonstrated in the image below. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate pharmacological agent to treat this patient’s condition?


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Binds to ergosterol and creates micropores
Inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to beta-glucan
Inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by conversion of 5-fluorocytosine to 5-fluorouracil

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and examination findings suggestive of onychomycosis. Onychomycosis is a clinical diagnosis that often presents with yellowish discoloration, splitting, and separation of the nail from the underlying nail bed.  Effective treatments include topical/oral azoles and oral/topical terbinafine. Terbinafine inhibits squalene epoxide, an enzyme involved in lanosterol synthesis, which results in the toxic accumulation of squalene.    

Adverse effects associated with terbinafine use include gastrointestinal disturbances and transaminitis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of squalene epoxidase :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of neutrophil migration :
Incorrect: Colchicine is an antiinflammatory agent that disrupts the neutrophil cytoskeleton and inhibits migration to sites of inflammation. Its use is indicated in the treatment of an acute gout flare. This patient’s presentation is suggestive of an alternative diagnosis. 
❌ Binds to ergosterol and creates micropores:
Incorrect: Nystatin inhibits fungal cell membrane functioning by creating micropores. Topical nystatin is not indicated in the treatment of dermatophyte infections. 
❌ Inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to beta-glucan :
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit fungal cell wall synthesis. Indications for its use include esophageal candidiasis and invasive aspergillosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of superficial dermatophyte infections. 
❌ Inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by conversion of 5-fluorocytosine to 5-fluorouracil :
Incorrect: Flucytosine inhibits nucleic acid synthesis in fungal cells. It is not indicated in the treatment of onychomycosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman at 20 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for evaluation of itching under her skin folds at the waist. Her past medical history includes hypothyroidism and allergic rhinitis. Current medications include levothyroxine and over-the-counter nasal decongestants. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals circular, erythematous, scaling plaques with central clearing about her waist and underneath her breasts. Skin scrapings are obtained and reveal segmented hyphae under KOH prep. Which of the following pharmacological agents would be contraindicated for treatment of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman presents with scaly, erythematous lesions in her skin folds suggestive of tinea corporis. Skin scrapings that reveal segmented hyphae are also characteristic of this dermatophyte infection. Tinea corporis responds well to topical antifungal agents including azoles, terbinafine, and griseofulvin. Of the medications listed, only griseofulvin is contraindicated as it carries teratogenic effects.    

Griseofulvin is used for a variety of superficial fungal infections. Mechanistically, it interferes with microtubule function and as a result, disrupts mitosis of the fungal cell.    

Specifically, griseofulvin is indicated in the treatment of superficial dermatophyte infections unresponsive to topical therapy. Adverse effects associated with its use include gastrointestinal disturbances, headache, photosensitivity, and hypersensitivity.    

In addition, griseofulvin is a CYP450 inducer and must be prescribed with caution and adjustments to patients taking warfarin, phenytoin, or other medications metabolized by the CYP450 system. Patients on griseofulvin must be advised to abstain from alcohol during the treatment period, as disulfiram-like reactions may occur.  



Option Analysis

❌ Terbinafine :
Incorrect: Terbinafine is employed in the treatment of extensive or refractory cutaneous dermatophyte infections. It can be prescribed during pregnancy. Patients with hepatic dysfunction should not be treated with terbinafine, because it poses a risk of severe hepatotoxicity. 
❌ Topical Clotrimazole:
Incorrect: Topical azole agents are not contraindicated in pregnancy. Oral use is avoided as it poses the risk of miscarriages and birth defects. 
❌ Topical Miconazole :
Incorrect: Topical azole antifungal agents are not contraindicated in pregnancy. Most azole agents used for superficial dermatophyte infections are administered for topical use. 
✅ Griseofulvin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Topical Ketoconazole :
Incorrect: Hepatic injury following azole use is common and can range from mild elevation of transaminases to acute hepatitis. Topical azole agents are not contraindicated in pregnancy

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic for treatment of a pruritic and blistering rash on the legs, which developed around two days ago. He has been using over-the-counter ointments without relief. He recently went camping and thinks he may have been exposed to poison ivy. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are multiple bullae in a linear distribution on a bright red erythematous base on the bilateral shins. The patient is prescribed a 3-week oral prednisone taper to manage his symptoms. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient was prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to treat allergic contact dermatitis caused by point ivy. Among the answer choices, only sleep disturbance is associated with glucocorticoid therapy.    

Glucocorticoids are pharmacologically similar to endogenous cortisol. They are often used for their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. Glucocorticoids can treat conditions including Addison disease, allergic reactions, autoimmune diseases, chronic inflammatory diseases, and asthma.    

Glucocorticoids exert physiologic effects on multiple organ systems and thus have a wide range of side effects, as detailed in the following table:  



Option Analysis

✅ Sleep disturbance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are associated with hyperglycemia and an increased risk of diabetes mellitus. This side effect is due to increased gluconeogenesis and insulin resistance.
❌ Leukopenia:
Incorrect: While glucocorticoids use is associated with a decreased lymphocyte, eosinophil, monocyte, and basophil count, the medication also leads to demargination of white blood cells (primarily neutrophils) from the blood vessel walls. These changes ultimately result in an artificially elevated white blood cell count on laboratory testing.
❌ Weight loss:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are associated with dose- and duration-dependent weight gain. This side effect is due to numerous contributing factors, including increased edema and metabolic changes.
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are associated with hypertension. This side effect usually occurs at higher doses due to the upregulation of α1-adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a painful rash for the past three days. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 137/70 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. The patient’s rash is shown in the image below. Which of the following medications should be administered at this time?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with herpes zoster infection (shingles). The most appropriate initial step in management for patients presenting within 3 days of symptom onset involves administration of an antiviral medication, such as valacyclovir.

Herpes zoster infection, also known as shingles, occurs in individuals who have had a primary infection with the varicella-zoster virus. Following the primary infection (“chickenpox”), the virus remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia of spinal nerves or the trigeminal ganglion. In times of stress or immunosuppression, the virus can reactivate and travel down the sensory neurons, causing herpes zoster.

Patients with herpes zoster classically present with a unilateral rash that does not cross the midline that is present in 1 or 2 adjacent dermatomes. The rash initially begins as a maculopapular rash that progresses to vesicles and may coalesce to bullae. The rash typically lasts between 10-15 days. Patients often describe a prodrome of malaise, headache, and low grade fever prior to the appearance of the rash. If individuals present within three days of rash onset, antiviral therapy with medications such as acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir can be administered.

Certain patient populations are at risk for disseminated herpes zoster, which can present with associated hepatitis, encephalitis, or meningitis. This can occur in patients with compromised immune systems, such as those with hematopoietic stem cell transplants, uncontrolled HIV, or malignancies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Valacyclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Valganciclovir:
Incorrect: Valganciclovir is indicated in the management of cytomegalovirus. This patient's presentation is consistent with herpes zoster.  
❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: Gabapentin is indicated for post-herpetic neuralgia secondary to herpes zoster; however, it is not does not treat the zoster infection.  
❌ Ritonavir:
Incorrect: Ritonavir is an antiviral medication used to treat HIV, not herpes zoster.  
❌ Subosivir:
Incorrect: Subosivir is a medication used to treat hepatitis C, not herpes zoster.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for follow-up of persistent pain following herpes zoster. The patient noticed a painful, erythematous, vesicular rash on her back that began over three months ago. The rash crusted over and improved, but she continues to have persistent, sharp, burning pain over the site of the rash. She has been applying the prescribed topical capsaicin and lidocaine without relief. She completed a full course of acyclovir. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. There is evidence of a well-healed rash over the left lower back that is tender to touch. The patient demonstrates hyperesthesia with light touch over this area. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to prescribe?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) secondary to herpes zoster infection (shingles). She has continued to have symptoms despite topical therapies. Thus, a medication to target nerve pain, such as gabapentin, would be appropriate to prescribe at this time.

Postherpetic neuralgia occurs due to viral replication and inflammation in sensory ganglia that eventually lead to neuron damage. Patients with PHN can experience continued pain that has not resolved months to years after the resolution of the rash. It can be diagnosed if the pain lasts for more than three months after the appearance of the initial rash. The most appropriate initial step in management involves administration of topical analgesics, such as lidocaine or capsaicin. If these do not provide relief, agents like gabapentin, pregabalin, or tricyclic antidepressants that treat neuropathic pain should be given.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gabapentin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Valacyclovir:
Incorrect: Valacyclovir is indicated in the management of acute herpes zoster infection. However, it does not provide benefit in the treatment of postherpetic neuralgia.  
❌ An additional course of acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is indicated in the management of acute herpes zoster infection. However, a repeat course of acyclovir would not provide benefit for postherpetic neuralgia.  
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Administration of glucocorticoids in the acute setting of herpes zoster may assist with reducing acute pain and faster healing. However, it would not be helpful to prescribe it at this time for postherpetic neuralgia.  
❌ Valproic acid:
Incorrect: This antiepileptic medication is indicated only if there are contraindications or an inadequate response to the preferred treatments for postherpetic neuralgia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of painful swelling and erythema on his right leg. The patient reports that he suffered minor cuts a few days ago while he was cleaning his garage. A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an indurated lesion surrounded by minor lacerations which are draining a purulent exudate. Complete blood profile shows a leukocyte count of 14,000 /mm3. Empiric antibiotic treatment is started after obtaining a sample of discharge for culture and sensitivity. Results of the culture reveal gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of resistance to methicillin in this bacteria?

choices.text: Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps
Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase
Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with painful erythematous swelling on right leg draining purulent exudate is most likely suffering from cellulitis. Gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin is consistent with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection.  

Resistance to methicillin and other β-lactams is due to one of the following mechanisms: 
  • Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP) altering its affinity for β-lactams (basis of methicillin resistance in staphylococci and of penicillin resistance in pneumococci and most resistant enterococci) 
  •  Inactivation of antibiotics by β-lactamase (penicillinases) is the most common mechanism of resistance of  staphylococci and many Gram-negative organisms 
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs, which is only in Gram-negative species because of the impermeable outer membrane of their cell wall 
  •  Efflux pump that efficiently transports some β-lactam antibiotics from the periplasm back across the cell wall outer membrane

Option Analysis

❌ Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps:
Incorrect: Decreased uptake or Increased efflux of the drug out of bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps is the mechanism of resistance of tetracyclines.
❌ Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolones is due primarily to chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase.
✅ Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis.
❌ Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan:
Incorrect: Resistance to vancomycin is caused by a change in the peptide component of peptidoglycan from D-alanyl-D-alanine, which is the normal binding site for vancomycin, to D-alanine-D-lactate, to which the drug does not bind.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care office for a rash. He has had an itchy patch of skin on his right arm for six weeks which has not improved with over-the-counter steroid cream. He has not had a fever and has not been in contact with any new materials or outdoor plants. He is not currently being treated for any chronic medical conditions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On examination, the patient is awake and alert and in no distress. Ear, nose, and throat examinations are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals no abnormalities. A skin rash is seen on the right elbow as pictured below. Pinpoint bleeding is noted when a small area of the rash is removed. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with this patient’s underlying condition? 



Image by Li X, Li J, Wang L, Niu X, Hou R, Liu R, Hao Z, Wang C, Yin G, Zhang K - Blood cancer journal (2015) was cropped from original, licensed under CC BY 4.0, reproduced from Open-i

choices.text: Prodrome of malaise     Dermatomal pattern     Hyperalgesia of affected area
Recent medication use     Erythematous papules with a dusky center     Widespread location
Flexor surfaces affected     History of food allergies     History of asthma

questions.solution:
This patient’s persistent, pruritic skin rash as pictured is concerning for psoriasis, a chronic immune-mediated condition that causes inflammation of the skin. Erythematous plaques covered by silvery-white scales are classic for psoriasis and are typically found on extensor surfaces. The rash is usually worse in the winter and better in the summer and may be associated with painful inflammation of the joints leading to sausage-shaped swelling of the fingers and toes, known as dactylitis. Removal of scales from a psoriatic plaque will often cause pin-point bleeding (Auspitz sign).        

The diagnostic workup of common skin rashes can be approached by first determining which of three main categories of rashes is present: cutaneous adverse medication reaction, infectious etiology, or inflammatory/autoimmune etiology. Features such as recent medication exposures, risk factors for infection, rash appearance, and associated features help narrow the differential. In this case, a localized rash, not associated with recent medication use, rules out cutaneous adverse medication rash. The absence of features suggestive of folliculitis (pustules over hair follicles, recent sweating or hot tub use), scabies (severe itching, worse at night, with serpiginous burrows and papules), shingles (vesicles in a dermatomal pattern with local hyperalgesia), tinea corporis (annular/ovoid itchy patches with a scaly edge and possible central clearing) and the lack of classic features of other common skin infections such as Lyme disease make an infectious cause unlikely.          

When adverse medication rash and infectious etiology have been ruled out, an inflammatory/autoimmune cause should be considered. Classic diagnostic features of conditions such as atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, acne vulgaris, rosacea, and psoriasis should be looked for, as the diagnosis of these conditions is primarily clinical. Skin testing or biopsy may be useful if a clinical diagnosis cannot be made or if patients fail to respond to empiric treatments.   

Option Analysis

✅  Extensor surfaces affected     Dactylitis     Rash worse in winter    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Prodrome of malaise     Dermatomal pattern     Hyperalgesia of affected area    :
Incorrect: A vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern with hyperalgesia of the affected area is classic for the rash of herpes zoster (shingles); a prodrome of malaise or fever may precede the skin lesions. This patient’s scaly rash on an erythematous base is classic for psoriasis.  
❌  Recent medication use     Erythematous papules with a dusky center     Widespread location    :
Incorrect: A widespread rash presenting as erythematous papules with a dusky center after recent medication use is classic for erythema multiforme, a cutaneous adverse medication reaction. This patient’s rash is consistent with psoriasis, which can be worsened by certain medications, but does not share the other classic findings of erythema multiforme. 
❌  Telangiectasias     Rhinophyma     Dryness of eyes    :
Incorrect: While psoriasis can affect the eyes, telangiectasias and the presence of rhinophyma are characteristic of rosacea. 
❌  Flexor surfaces affected     History of food allergies     History of asthma    :
Incorrect: Involvement of flexor surfaces and a history of food allergies and asthma are commonly seen with atopic dermatitis. This patient’s lesion is more characteristic of psoriasis, presenting as an erythematous plaque with silvery scale.
